results.title: Le Miracle des Loups = the Miracle of the Wolves
results.brief_description:
Robert Cottereau, standard bearer of Charles, duke of Burgundy, is in love with Jeanne Fouquet, god-daughter of King Louis XI. During a ball given by Charles, Lord Chateauneuf, a member of Louis XI’s party, tries to rape Jeanne. This causes a rupture between the King and the Duke and a war between France and Burgundy. Robert and Jeanne are separated. When Jeanne, carrying a secret letter from the King to Burgundy, is pursued by Chateauneuf, she benefits from the protection of a pack of wolves. This story was originally filmed by Raymond Bernard in 1924.

Credits: Producers, Paul Cadeac, Rene Bezard ; director, Andre Hunebelle ; writers, Jean Halain, Pierre Foucaud, Andre Hunebelle ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Jean Marion.
Cast: Jean Marais, Rossana Schiaffino, Roger Hanin, Jean-Louis Barrault, Louis Arbessier.

results.title: Pepe le Moko
results.creator_credit: Julien Duvivier, Raymond Hakim and Robert Hakim
results.brief_description:
Pepe, a fugitive jewel thief lives as a gang leader in the Algerian Casbah. He is protected from justice as long as he makes no attempt to leave, but when he falls in love with a visiting Parisienne, he risks his freedom to be with her. ‘Pepe le Moko’ is the epitome of 1930s French cinema and created the myth of the doomed, romantic anti-hero. This film also served to establish Jean Gabin as a major star. A romantic, atmospheric thriller, it was crucial to the development of ‘French film noir’ and inspired a number of remakes and many imitations. Duvivier admitted that ‘Pepe’ was inspired by American ganster films, especially Howard Hawks’ ‘Scarface’. In ‘Pepe’, the gangster Max who plays the cup-and-ball is a reminder of the coin-tossing ganster played by Georges Raft in ‘Scarface’. The Algiers Casbah was fully reconstituted in studio. A few exteriors were shot on location in Sete and Marseilles. Only a few establishing shot were filmed in Algiers. ‘Pepe le Moko’ was remade in the US as ‘Algiers’ (1938) and as ‘Casbah’ (1948). Further reading: Ginette Vincendeau. ‘Pepe le Moko’. London: BFI Film Classics, 1998.

Credits: Producers, Robert and Raymond Hakim ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Pierre Ashelbe, Julien Duvivier, Henri Jeanson ; photography, Jules Kruger ; music, Vincent Scotto, Mohamed Yguerbouchen ; art direction, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Mireille Balin, Line Noro, Fernand Charpin, Saturnin Fabre, Gabriel Gabrio, Marcel Dalio, Frehel.

results.title: La Bible = the Bible
results.brief_description:
This version of the Bible is illustrated by the mosaics of Monreale, near Palermo (Sicily).

Credits: Producer, Andre Tranche ; director, Marcel Carne ; writers, Marcel Carne, Didier Decoin ; photography, Jean Collomb ; music, Jean-Pierre Benjamin.

results.title: Aloise
results.creator_credit: Liliane de Kermadec and Alain Dahan
results.brief_description:
The painful life of a mentally unstable but highly gifted woman is unveiled in this film, based on episodes from the life of an actual person. Aloise creates a series of haunting drawings while she is incarcerated in an institution for the insane in turn-of-the-century Switzerland. She endures torments as a musically gifted girl and later as a young woman; her developing madness and the barbaric treatments of the time are shown.

Credits: Producer, Alain Dahan ; director, Liliane de Kermadec ; writers, Liliane de Kermadec, Andre Techine ; photography, Jean Penzer.
Cast: Roger Blin, Delphine Seyrig, Jacques Weber, Isabelle Huppert, Julien Guiomar, Michel Lonsdale.

results.title: Le Soleil En Face = Face to the Sun
results.creator_credit: Pierre Kast, Humbert Balsan, Serge Marquand and Stephane Tchalgadjieff
results.brief_description:
The writer Marat has exiled himself with his family to a small Portugese village, Tavira. He is cared for by his wife, Genevieve. The family doctor informs Genevieve that Marat is dying of cancer. She tries to hide the news from her husband who manages to find out about his illness anyway. Meanwhile, a television programme extends an invitation to Marat to film a portrait.

Credits: Producers, Humbert Balsan, Serge Marquand, Stephane Tchalgadjieff ; director, Pierre Kast ; writers, Pierre Kast, Alain Aptekman ; photography, Gerard de Battista ; music, Sergio Godinho.
Cast: Jean-PIerre Cassel, Stephane Audran, Alexandra Stewart, Pierre Vaneck, Beatrice Bruno.

results.title: On N'enterre Pas le Dimanche = No Funeral on Sundays
results.brief_description:
Philippe, a West Indian student, helps his Swedish girfriend, Margaretha, find a job as a secretary in a publishing house. Philippe has written a novel and the publisher’s wife promise to help with the publishing of the novel in exchange for some special favours from Philippe. Awards: Prix Louis Delluc 1959.

Credits: Director, Michel Drach ; writers, Eric Ollivier, Michel Drach ; photography, Jean Tournier ; music, Eric Dixon, Kenny Clarke.
Cast: Christina Bendz, Philippe Mory, Hella Petri, Albert Gilou, Marcel Cuvelier.

results.title: La Triche = the Cheat
results.brief_description:
Michel Verta, a police officer, lives happy in Bordeaux with his wife Nathalie and their child. From time to time he indulges in homosexual encounters. During a routine crime enquiry in a night-club, he meets Bernard, a musician, with whom he falls in love. Michel’s family finds out, and their reactions to the news are quite predictable. When Bernard accidentally kills a man who has been blackmailing him, the gay couple’s troubles are intensified, especially since Michel tries to illegally protect Bernard. The two lovers are caught in an increasing spiral of lies and despair.

Credits: Producer, Denise Petitdidier ; director, Yannick Bellon ; writers, Yannick Bellon, Alain Marcel, Remi Waterhouse ; photography, Houchang Baharlou ; music, Catherine Lara.
Cast: Victor Lanoux, Xavier Deluc, Anny Duperey, Michel Galabru, Valerie Mairesse, Michel Galabru.

results.title: Les Anciens de Saint-Loup = the Old Boys of Saint-Loup
results.brief_description:
Thre former students of the St Loup college reunite to investigate the mysterious murder of the director’s niece.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Roitfeld ; director, Georges Lampin ; writers, Pierre Very, Georges Lampin ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Georges van Parys.
Cast: Bernard Blier, Odile Versois, Francois Perier, Monique Melinand, Serge Reggiani.

results.title: Les Maitres du Temps = the Time Masters
results.creator_credit: Rene Laloux, Jacques Dercourt and Roland Gritti
results.brief_description:
His name is Piel. He is four years old. He is the last survivor of planet Perdide. How could he outsmart the dangers of a planet that has already claimed the lives of his parents and recognise the poisonous fruits and the venimous flowers? His last link with the world of humans is a radio transmitter whose distress signals have been received by Grand Max, a traveller with a generous heart. Max uses the radio to keep watch on the orphan while trying to organise a rescue mission. Stephan Wul (born 1922) is one of the pioneers of French science-fiction writing. Jean Giraud, by the name of Moebius, revolutionised the universe of fictional comics, creating a special and magical atmosphere around his stories. He is credited with inspiring the visual imagery of works such as ‘Blade Runner’ and ‘The Fifth Element’. Further reading: Gianalberto Bendazzi. ‘Rene Laloux. Drawings That Move’. Animation World: April 1996 (Vol. 1, No.1). Online. http://www.awn.com/mag/issue1.1/

Credits: Producers, Roland Gritti, Jacques Dercourt ; director, Rene Laloux ; writers, Rene Laloux, Moebius (Jean Giraud), Jean-Patrick Manchette ; photography, Mihaly Kovacs, Andras Klausz, Zoltan Basco, Arpad Lossonczy ; music, Jean-Pierre Bourtayre
Cast: Sady Rebbot, Frederic Legros, Jean Valmont, Yves Marie, Pierre Tourneur, Alain Cuny [voices only].

results.title: Les Seins de Glace = Icy Breasts
results.creator_credit: Georges Lautner, Alain Delon and Raymond Danon
results.brief_description:
Francois Rollin, a TV writer, meets a lonely woman on the beach and pushes his way into her life. Peggy lives alone in a grand mansion with a groundkeeper cum spy. Rilsen, a lawyer, who is secretely in love with Peggy, is trying his best to push Rollin away from Peggy. But to no avail. The mysteries, the silences and the strange men surrounding Peggy only contribute to tease the TV writer’s curiosity. As Rollin delves further into Peggy’s past, he discovers that she has killed every man who has ever gotten close to her.

Credits: Producers, Raymond Danon, Alain Delon ; director, Georges Lautner ; writer, Georges Lautner ; photography, Maurice Fellous ; music, Philippe Sarde ; second assistant director, Robin Davis.
Cast: Mireille Darc, Alain Delon, Claude Brasseur, Nicoletta Machiavelli, Andre Falcon.
